awd_abstract_narration:
With this CAREER Award, the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Division of Chemistry is supporting the research of Professor Indrajeet Sharma at the University of Oklahoma.  Professor Sharma is developing new synthetic methods for the construction of the types of bioactive molecules that are frequently used in efforts to identify drug leads for the treatment of cancer, infectious diseases, and neurological disorders. The research described seeks to develop cascade reactions that take advantage of a sequence of carefully timed steps to convert inexpensive, readily accessible compounds into higher-value, complex molecules. To accomplish this, the Sharma group is developing new reaction protocols that involve the use of more than one metal at a time. This research is expected to have broad application in the fields of chemical synthesis, medicinal chemistry, and therapeutics development.  Professor Sharma is also pioneering an outreach program, the Synergistic Catalytic Cycle for Education Excellence  (SC2E2), that provides crucial hands-on science education for underrepresented students in the State of Oklahoma. The SC2E2 program encourages an increase in school enrollment, retention, and graduation rates of highly qualified STEM students from low-income areas in the State of Oklahoma.

Despite dramatic advances in natural product-inspired drug discovery, many bioactive scaffolds (spirocycles, medium-sized rings, and terpene furanolactones) remain underexploited in drug discovery screening owing to the challenges associated with their synthesis. To address these challenges, this research program will utilize metal carbene cascade reactions for the efficient scalable synthesis of such scaffolds. More specifically, this research focuses on the use of diazo-derived metal-carbenes that are ambiphilic in nature in combination with a second metal catalyst to trigger sequential reactions with a nucleophile and an electrophile. The ensuing cascade reactions lead to the rapid generation of molecular complexity. A comprehensive educational plan is also integrated with the research goals to provide an inclusive scientific education experience for students from underrepresented groups in the State of Oklahoma. The proposed SC2E2 program is inspired from developed research involving synergistic catalysis, in which two or more catalysts act simultaneously to improve the efficiency of existing transformations. Likewise, SC2E2 builds upon inclusive educational practices in a cyclic process by providing students training, guidance and leadership opportunities, which ultimately help cultivate a new generation of diverse STEM professionals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Overview: This National Science Foundation (NSF) funded initiative has achieved significant advancements in sustainable chemical synthesis through the development of innovative catalytic processes that leverage earth-abundant metals, including iron, copper, and zinc, in conjunction with visible light and metal-free methods that utilize metallomimetic sulfur-based carbenes and nitrenes. These methodologies provide cost-effective and environmentally friendly alternatives to the precious metals traditionally employed in chemical transformations, such as rhodium and gold. Our research has facilitated the discovery of novel catalytic systems designed explicitly for carbene cascade reactions, which are essential to progressing pharmaceutical research and chemical manufacturing while minimizing environmental consequences.

Intellectual Merit: We have successfully developed transformations for carbenes and nitrenes utilizing earth-abundant metals such as iron, copper, and zinc, or under metal-free conditions. This advancement represents an effective, sustainable solution for complex chemical reactions, significantly reducing reliance on expensive and toxic precious metals. Noteworthy is the breakthrough involving the creation of sulfur-based carbenes and nitrenes that are devoid of additives and metal, thereby providing improved functional group compatibility alongside substantial environmental benefits.

Broader Impacts:

1. Development of Human Resources in Science: The Principal Investigator (PI) has successfully graduated six Ph.D. and six M.S. students, mentored twenty-four undergraduate students, and supervised seven postdoctoral fellows, in addition to currently overseeing nine Ph.D. candidates and three undergraduates. Former trainees have embarked on successful careers in federal agencies, postdoctoral research positions, medical and dental schools, and various industries, with the research group securing $185,000 in graduate fellowships and $55,000 in undergraduate awards.

Selected Alumni and Current Positions:

Ph.D. Graduates:

- Arianne Hunter, Ph.D. (Senior Scientist at AbbVie, SMART fellow DOD, Recipient of Best Ph.D. Thesis, CAS Future Leader 2019)

- Ana Bain, Ph.D. (Senior Scientist at Eli Lilly, First Prize Winner of the OU-wide 3-Minute Thesis Competition)

- Adam Alber, Ph.D. (Tenure-Track Assistant Professor, Northwest Oklahoma State University)

Undergraduate Students:

- Ibikari Legg-Jack (M.D. Student, University of Pennsylvania Medical School, Full Tuition Waiver)

- Haylee Padgett (M.D. Student, University of Cincinnati Medical School)

- Katelyn Stevens (Ph.D. Student, University of Minnesota)

- Ginny Kim (Ph.D. Student, University of Notre Dame)

- Adrianne Daroczi (Ph.D. student, University of Oxford)

Postdoctoral Fellows:

- Kiran Chinthapally (Scientist, University of Notre Dame)

- Dinesh Paymode (Scientist, Mirati Therapeutics)

- Bidhan Ghosh (Scientist, Syngene)

Moreover, the PI has provided training to underrepresented students, including four NSF-LSAMP scholars, three McNair Scholars, one NSF-EPSCoR-REU scholar, and two NIH-INBRE awardees.

2. Educational Experiences: Research findings have been integrated into the advanced organic chemistry laboratory (CHEM-4444) at the University of Oklahoma, allowing students to gain practical experience in advanced techniques including Schlenk methods, HPLC, and NMR spectroscopy. This experiential learning approach has significantly enhanced students' critical thinking and problem-solving skills in modern chemical research.

3. Public Engagement and Outreach: The initiative has bolstered public awareness of scientific research through outreach efforts, including presentations at public libraries and the Osher Lifelong Learning Institute (OLLI). These sessions elucidated the drug discovery process and highlighted the societal benefits of scientific innovation. In collaboration with Chris Elliott, director of the Pre-Collegiate Programs at OU, the Sharma laboratory has hosted an annual week-long chemistry academy for 11th and 12th grade students from Oklahoma, with thirty students participating, including over fifty percent from underrepresented groups. The students reside in university residence halls with counselors housed on the same floor for maximum support and supervision. Pre- and post-learning assessments are conducted to evaluate the program's efficacy. A notable outreach activity included Dr. Sharma's presentation titled "Drug Discovery: Public Health or Corporate Wealth" at the Summer Science Program (SSP) at Southwestern Oklahoma State University, which inspired high school students to pursue careers in science and comprehend the significance of public funding in medical research. Please see the attached images with highschool students.

Sustainability and Environmental Impact: By advancing catalytic processes utilizing iron, copper, and zinc, this project advocates for sustainable chemical practices and aims to diminish the environmental footprint associated with chemical synthesis. These methodologies present the potential to reduce costs in pharmaceuticals and other essential chemicals while concurrently lowering dependence on environmentally detrimental precious metal mining.


Last Modified: 03/24/2025
Modified by: Indrajeet Sharma
